metadata.title: Graphene Wrapped FeSe2 Nano-Microspheres with High Pseudocapacitive Contribution for Enhanced Na-Ion Storage

sections.text:
www.advenergymat.de
Full paper
1900356 (1 of 9) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim

sections.heading: Graphene Wrapped FeSe2 Nano-Microspheres with High Pseudocapacitive Contribution for Enhanced Na-Ion Storage
Changsheng An, Yifei Yuan, Bao Zhang, Linbo Tang, Bin Xiao, Zhenjiang He,
Junchao Zheng,* and Jun Lu*
sections.text:
DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201900356
larger radius (0.102 vs 0.076 nm for Na+ vs Li+) and heavier molar mass (22.99 vs 6.94 g mol−1 for Na+ vs Li+), Na+ ion diffusion in the electrode materials is more difficult than Li+.[2] Consequently, the large volume change, low specific capacity, inferior rate capability, and poor cycling stability of the electrode materials during the discharge/charge significantly plague the application of SIBs. It thus remains a grand challenge to suppress the volume change during the discharge/charge process, and to further improve the electronic conductivity of the electrode materials for high-performance SIBs.
Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), such as MoSe2,[3] CoSe2,[4] FeS2,[5] and MoS2,[2a] have received considerable amount of attention as the promising anode materials for SIBs because of their high theoretical capacity and widespread availability. Among them, FeSe2 has attracted great interest due to its abundant resources, low toxicity, high theoretical capacity and environment-friendliness.[6] However, as similar as other TMDs, the
development of FeSe2 is limited by the large volume change during the discharge/charge process, resulting in the severe capacity fade caused by unstable structure and poor rate capability induced by electrode pulverization and particle aggregation.[6b] Enormous efforts have been conducted to overcome the issues, while encapsulating the FeSe2 into the carbon matrix is considered as effective approach.[7] For example, Zhang et al.[6c] prepared FeSe2 microspheres interspersed into sulfur-doped reduced graphene oxide sheets as a promising anode for SIBs, displaying an excellent electrochemical performance. It indicates that combining FeSe2 with carbon can suppress the volume change and enhance the electrochemical properties during the continuous sodiation/desodiation process.[7] Whereas, the reaction kinetic with high-rate capability of FeSe2 anode is rarely concerned, which is still needed to address. Although incorporating conductive materials or constructing nanosized structure, the rate ability of FeSe2-based anodes is still far from satisfactory.
Generally, apart from the conventional diffusion-controlled behavior in the electrochemical processes, pseudocapacitivecontrolled contribution, as a fast charge-transfer reactions based on the featuring Faradaic surface, plays a crucial role
Pseudocapacitance is a Faradaic process that involves surface or near surface redox reactions. Increasing the pseudocapacitive contribution is one of the most effective means to improve the rate performance of electrode materials. In this study, graphene oxide is used as a template to in situ synthesize burr globule-like FeSe2/graphene hybrid (B-FeSe2/G) using a facile one-step hydrothermal method. Structural characterization demonstrates that graphene layers not only wrap the surfaces of FeSe2 particles, but also stretch into the interior of these particles, as a result of which the unique nano-microsphere structure is successfully established. When serving as anode material for Na-ion batteries, B-FeSe2/G hybrid displays high electrochemical performance in the voltage range of 0.5–2.9 V. The B-FeSe2/G hybrid has high reversible capacity of 521.6 mAh·g−1 at 1.0 A g−1. Meanwhile, after 400 cycles, high discharge capacity of 496.3 mAh g−1 is obtained at a rate of 2.5 A g−1, with a high columbic efficiency of 96.6% and less than 1.0% loss of discharge capacity. Even at the ultrahigh rate of 10 A g−1, a specific capacity of 316.8 mAh g−1 can be achieved. Kinetic analyses reveal that the excellent performance of the B-FeSe2/G hybrid is largely attributed to the high pseudocapacitive contribution induced by the special nano-micro structure.
Dr. C. An, Prof. B. Zhang, Dr. L. Tang, Dr. B. Xiao, Prof. Z. He, Prof. J. Zheng School of Metallurgy and Environment Central South University Changsha 410083, China E-mail: jczheng@csu.edu.cn Dr. Y. Yuan, Dr. J. Lu Chemical Sciences and Engineering Division Argonne National Laboratory Lemont, IL 60439, USA E-mail: junlu@anl.gov
The ORCID identification number(s) for the author(s) of this article can be found under https://doi.org/10.1002/aenm.201900356.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the escalation of serious energy crisis, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) can barely meet the increasing energy demand for modern society due to the limited resources and increasing cost of lithium.[1] As the alternative to LiBs, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) is quite promising due to the low cost, abundant resource and environmental friendliness of Na. However, because of its
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1900356
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900356 (2 of 9)
for the electrochemical performance of SIBs, leading to the high-rate capability.[8] And pseudocapacitance can be intrinsic (such as RuO2,[9] MnO2,[10] and Nb2O5,[11] etc.) and extrinsic (such as LiCoO2,[12] TiO2,[13] and V2O5,[14] etc.) to a material.[8c] In addition, some hybrids have been successfully synthesized with unique structure with high pesudocapacitance, such as mesoporous structure, nanofilm, nanoparticles, etc., overcoming the sluggish kinetics and achieving the high-rate capability.[10,14]
In this study, the self-templated B-FeSe2/G hybrid has been prepared by a one-step hydrothermal method, as illustrated in Scheme 1. First, the positively charged GO was prepared by noncovalent functionalization using poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA). Then the negatively charged FeSe2 particles (Figure S1, Supporting Information) adsorbed on the surface of GO during hydrothermal process. Finally, the specific nano-microspheres of FeSe2/G were obtained after the hydrothermal process. It is noted that the graphene nanosheets are not only wrapping around the surface and but also interspersing into the interior of the FeSe2, resulting in the formation of nano-microspheres. It is also well recognized that electrode materials with selfassembled nano/micro hierarchical structures is one of the most strategy of choice to improve the sodium storage performance and pesudocapacitance.[10,15]As an anode material for SIBs, the as-prepared B-FeSe2/G composite exhibits improved electrochemical performance in terms of high reversible capacity and superior rate capability. Besides, a high pseudocapacitive contribution for the Na-ion storage is revealed by cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests. This phenomenon can be ascribed to the improvement of pseudocapacitive contribution because
of their unique morphology of nano-microsphere, leading to the improved electrical conductivity and suppressed volume change during the discharge/charge process. More important, to fully explore the FeSe2 anode, it is necessary to understand reaction mechanism so that improving its electrochemical performances.

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussions
sections.text:
X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G hybrids are displayed in Figure 1 and FeSe2 with different contents of GO-PDDA are shown in Figure S2 in the Supporting Information. The diffraction peaks of all samples are in agreement with that of orthorhombic phase of FeSe2 (PDF#79-1892). No additional peaks are observed, indicating the high crystallinity of FeSe2 phase without any impurity. Moreover, the phases of B-FeSe2/G hybrid maintain unchanged after graphene interspersing, suggesting the little effect of graphene on the structure. The Raman spectrum of the as-prepared purity P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G composites is shown in Figure 1b,c. The peaks of both samples at 181.5 and 218.1 cm−1 correspond to the rocking and stretching vibration of Se–Se bonds or their combination (Figure 1b; Figure S2b, Supporting Information).[6a] The existence of carbon is characterized by Raman spectra (Figure 1c), and the intensity ratio of the D band to the G band (ID/IG) is 1.47 for B-FeSe2/G and 0.97 for P-FeSe2. The findings confirm that the amount of defects and the disordering degree of the graphene are increased after the hydrothermal process, accompanied with a reduction process from GO to rGO.[16]
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1900356
Scheme 1. Illustration of the fabrication of B-FeSe2/G.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900356 (3 of 9)
The morphology and microstructure of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G hybrids are confirmed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The P-FeSe2 displays irregular small particles with diameter of 30–50 nm (Figure 2a,b). The FeSe2 particles are coated by a thin layer of amorphous carbon (Figure 2c). While the agglomerated secondary particles of B-FeSe2/G hybrid displays a burr globulelike morphology with a diameter of about 3–4 µm, while the graphene nanosheets are wrapping and interspersing in the interior and surface of FeSe2 particles (Figure 2d,e). A lattice fringe with a d-spacing of ≈0.178 and 1.60 nm are observed in the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G hybrids, respectively, (Figure 2c,f), which are consistent with the (022) and (112) crystal planes of FeSe2.
Besides, the internal morphology and structure of B-FeSe2/G are further examined by focused-ion beam (FIB)–SEM analysis. From the SEM image (Figure 3a), many nanoburrs are formed on the surface of the microsphere. Meanwhile, the surface of FeSe2 nanoparticles is wrapped by the graphene nanosheets.
Notably, these graphene nanosheets also penetrate into the bulk of FeSe2 particles, which could thus significantly improve the bulk-level conductivity of the electrode. Remarkably, the cross-sectional SEM image further demonstrates that burr globule-like FeSe2 transform to solid microspheres with a large number of micropores (Figure 3b and inset). FeSe2 nanoparticles adsorbed on the surface of graphene nanosheets exhibit a strong tendency to self-assemble into nano-microspheres owing to the charged particle surfaces. Additionally, the coexistence of Se, Fe, and C elements are presented in the elemental mappings of cross-sectional B-FeSe2/G sample (Figure 3c–e), indicating that all elements are homogeneously distributed in the B-FeSe2/G nano-microspheres. The unique nano-microsphere structure can improve electrical conductivity of the B-FeSe2/G hybrid, and suppress the volume change during continuous charging–discharging processes.
The specific surface areas of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G hybrids are confirmed by the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms in Figure S3a in the Supporting Information.
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1900356
Figure 1. a) XRD patterns and b,c) Raman spectrum of the P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900356 (4 of 9)
Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G are calculated to be 9.89 and 19.97 m2 g−1, respectively. Moreover, both samples exhibit similar pore size of 3.40 nm from the desorption isotherm, whereas the B-FeSe2/G possesses larger pore volume (inset in Figure S3a in the Supporting Information). The increase in the specific area and pore volume can be ascribed to the introduction of graphene and formation of B-FeSe2/G nano-microspheres, which is beneficial for the contact between active materials and electrolyte, leading to the high pseudocapacitive contribution for enhancing Na-ion storage. The content of graphene in the B-FeSe2/G is calculated from thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) measurement (Figure S3b, Supporting Information). The weight loss is attributed to the decomposition of FeSe2 into Fe2O3 and SeO2, and the combustion of graphene. The weight percentage of graphene in B-FeSe2/G composite can be evaluated to be 9.92 wt%.
To investigate the formation process of the as-prepared B-FeSe2/G nano-microspheres, time-dependent experiments were performed. The morphologies of the as-prepared samples at different hydrothermal reaction time were characterized using SEM (Figure S4, Supporting Information). When the reaction time is 2 h, irregular nanoparticles are formed on the surface of graphene nanosheets (Figure S4a, Supporting Information). When the reaction time increases to 4 h, the irregular particles begin to transform into irregular rods (Figure S4b, Supporting Information). After 6 h, the irregular rods get further refinement (Figure S4c, Supporting Information). As the reaction time increases to 8 h, the irregular particles completely change to the regular rods (Figure S4d, Supporting Information).
The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) analysis was performed to obtain more details about the elemental information of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G (The survey spectrum of XPS
spectra for FeSe2 with different contents of GO-PDDA is shown in Figure S6, Supporting Information). The results indicate that both samples contain the main elements of Fe, Se, and C (Figure 4a). The high-resolution Fe 2p spectrum (Figure 4b) displays two major peaks at 707 and 720 eV coupled with two shake-up satellites (711 and 725 eV), corresponding to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2. The peaks of S 2p (Figure 4c) at 54.4 and 55.4 eV are attributed to S 3d5/2 and S 3d3/2, respectively, confirming the successful preparation of FeSe2.[7] Furthermore, the high-resolution C 1s peaks of (Figure 4d) at 284.7, 285.5, and 286.7 eV are attributed to the presence of CC, CO, and CO, suggesting the existence of graphene in the B-FeSe2/G hybrid. The atomic ratio of carbon to oxygen (C/O) is 2.75 for B-FeSe2/G (Table S1, Supporting Information), implying a certain reduction degree of GO to rGO after the hydrothermal process.[2a,17]
The electrochemical performance of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G as the anode materials for SIBs has been evaluated using CV and charge/discharge test. The CV profiles of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G electrode at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s−1 are shown in Figure 5a,b, respectively. Two reduction peaks at around 0.66 and 1.01 V and four oxidation peaks at 1.37, 1.52, 2.06, and 2.30 V are observed in the first cycle of CV profiles. The two discharge plateaus imply the intercalation reaction forming NaxFeSe2 and the following conversion reaction forming Na2Se at the first cycle (Equations (1) and (2)). Meanwhile, the four charge plateaus correspond to the reversible reaction from Na2Se to NaxFeSe2 and finally to the recovery of FeSe2 phase (Equations (3) and (4)). Compared to the P-FeSe2, the CV profiles of B-FeSe2/G overlap from the second cycle onward and remain stable, indicating the excellent reversibility and stability because of the specific nano-microspheres structure. The difference between the first and following cycles about the reduction and oxidation peaks are contributed to the activation process of
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1900356
Figure 3. a) SEM, b) FIB-SEM (inset is the EDS), and c–e) Elemental mapping images of the as-prepared B-FeSe2/G.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900356 (5 of 9)
electrode microstructure transformation and the formation of ultrafine FeSe2 nanocrystals during the first charge/discharge processes.
Meanwhile, the discharge/charge behavior of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G anodes in the potential window of 0.5–2.9 V at 0.05 A g−1 are shown in Figure 5c,d. When tested in the first cycle, both samples deliver two discharge potential plateaus and four charge plateaus, in agreement with the previous CV profiles (Figure 5a,b). The P-FeSe2 electrode exhibits the initial discharge capacity of 425.2 mAh g−1 with Coulombic efficiency of 92.0%, while it rapidly decreases to 390.3 mAh g−1 after five cycles. In contrast, the B-FeSe2/G displays a higher discharge capacity of 562.3 mAh g−1 at the first cycle with a high Coulombic efficiency of 93.1%. For the 5th cycle, it still remains a reversible capacity of 513.4 mAh g−1. Meanwhile, the potential plateaus of B-FeSe2/G almost overlap without any discrepancy, demonstrating the better cycling stability.
The cycling performance of the as-prepared P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G samples at various current densities from 0.05 to 10.0 A g−1 are displayed in Figure 5e,f. As expected, the B-FeSe2/G shows the high discharge capacity of ≈562.3, 511.9, 529.9, 532.2, 521.6, 496.3, 452.8, and 376.8 mAh g−1 at 0.05, 0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 1.0, 2.5, 5.0, and 7.5 A g−1, respectively. Even at a high rate of 10.0 A g−1, a discharge capacity of 323.7 mAh g−1 can be obtained. However, the discharge capacity decreases quickly for the P-FeSe2 sample, particularly under high rate of 5.0, 7.5, and 10 A g−1, where it only exhibits 222.6, 170.2, and 138.1 mAh g−1, respectively. The cycling performance at high rate of 2.5 A g−1 is also studied (Figure 5f; Figure S7b, Supporting Information). Before 100 cycles, the Coulombic efficiency (CE) of P-FeSe2 electrode of nearly 100% is
attributed to the good reaction kinetics, indicating the excellent cycling reversibility. However, the CE sharply decreased to below 100% after 100 cycles is assigned to the aggregation of the FeSe2 particles, the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film formation between electrode and electrolyte and the structural collapse of FeSe2 during the discharge/charge process. And the rate capability of the pure G is shown in Figure S7c in the Supporting Information. The B-FeSe2/G electrode exhibits a higher reversible capacity and more stable cycling performance, with more than 99% capacity retention after 400 cycles. In contrast, the capacity loss of P-FeSe2 is more than 12.5% after 400 cycles, and the Coulombic efficiency is higher than 100% at the beginning but drops abruptly to below 100% after 100 cycles, which should be ascribed to the collapse of the structure during the discharge/charge process. The high rate capability and excellent cycling stability of B-FeSe2/G composite is attributed to the nano-microspheres structure, which could effectively enhance the electrical conductivity and effectively suppressed the volume change during discharge/charge process.
In situ XRD was performed to further understand the intrinsic reaction mechanisms of B-FeSe2/G electrode. The in situ cell was discharged from open circuit voltage to 0.5 V and charged from 0.5 to 2.9 V (Figure 6a,b). As shown in Figure 6a, the as-prepared B-FeSe2/G electrode shows the characteristic peaks of FeSe2 at 30.9°, 34.8°, 36.2°, 48.2°, and 54.0°, respectively. While, the peaks located at 46.0°, 50.5°, and 52.5° are ascribed to the Be foil, and the peaks centered at 38.6°, 41.1°, and 43.9° are attributed to the BeO.[18] In addition, the peak at 26.5° is assigned to the carbon paper as current collector.[19] As shown in Figure 6b, the characteristic peaks of
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1900356
Figure 4. XPS spectra of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G. a) survey spectrum for P-FeSe2 and; b) Fe 2p, c) Se 3d; d) C 1s for B-FeSe2/G.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900356 (6 of 9)
FeSe2 slightly shift to the left and eventually disappear during the discharge process in the first cycle, suggesting that the formation of the NaxFeSe2 electrode because of the insertion of Na+-ions (Equation (1)). No obvious diffraction peaks appeared in the XRD pattern before the peak of Na2Se appeared, indicating the conversion reaction between NaxFeSe2 and Na+-ion and formation of metallic Fe0 (Equation (2)). Moreover, no obvious diffraction peaks of Fe0 appeared in the XRD pattern because of the low content and small particle size.[20] The Na2Se peaks gradually vanished during charge process, suggesting the reverse conversion reaction between Na2Se and Fe0 (Equation (3)). However, at fully charged state, the peaks of FeSe2 can hardly be observed, implying the poor crystallinity of FeSe2 after the discharge/charge process. During the second charge/discharge process, it demonstrates the similar phenomena and reaction procedures, and only the peaks of Na2Se can be observed, indicating the reversible reaction of B-FeSe2/G electrode.[18,19,21] The relevant chemical reaction equations are as following Discharge process equation + + →+ −FeSe Na e Na FeSe2 2x x x (1) + − + − → ++ −Na FeSe (4 )Na (4 )e 2Na Se Fe2 2x xx (2) Charge process equation x xxFe 2Na Se Na FeSe (4 )Na (4 )e2 2+ → + − + −+ − (3) → + ++ −Na FeSe FeSe Na e2 2 x xx (4) To explain the high electrochemical performance of B-FeSe2/G, CV profiles for the B-FeSe2/G electrode were obtained at different scan rates ranging from 0.2 to 1.0 mV s−1 (Figure 7a). Compared with the CV curves of P-FeSe2 (Figure S8a, Supporting Information), the CV curves
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1900356
Figure 5. Electrochemical performance of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s−1 in the voltage range of 0.5–2.9 V versus Na+/Na, charge/discharge profiles during five cycles at rate of 0.05 A g−1 of a,c) P-FeSe2 and b,d) B-FeSe2/G, respectively. Rate capability at various current densities from 0.05 to 10.0 A g−1, long-term cycling performance at a cyclic rate of 2.5 A g−1 of e,f) P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900356 (7 of 9)Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1900356
for the B-FeSe2/G exhibit a certain degree of overlap at different scan rates. This phenomenon implies the lower electrochemical polarization and better rate performance of the B-FeSe2/G. As the scan rate increases, the peak current increases without being proportional to the square root of the scan rate. Thus, the charge/discharge processes feature both non-Faradaic and Faradaic behaviors. The relationship between peak current (i) and scan rate (v) can be calculated by the Equations as following
=i avb (5)
= +log log logi b v a (6)
Where i and v are the peak current and scan rate, respectively. a and b are the adjustable parameters. The value of b determines the type of Na+ insertion/extraction during the electrochemical reaction (b = 0.5, ionic diffusion control; b = 1, pseudo-capacitive control).[10,15] The linear relationship between log i and log v plots presents in Figure 7b and Figure S8b
(Supporting Information) at various peak potential. The b values for P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G are 0.49, 0.76, 0.83, and 0.88, 1.09, 0.90, respectively. This result indicates that the electrochemical reactions of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G are mainly controlled by the pseudocapacitive behavior.
To quantify the total capacitive and diffusion contribution in the samples, the results are calculated according to the following Equation
= +(V) 1 2 1 2i k v k v (7)
The Equation (7) can also be reformulated as
= +(V)/ 1/2 1 1/2 2i v k v k (8)
Where i (V) is the total current response at a given potential V, k1 and k2 are the capacitive and diffusion contribution, respectively. The separations of the capacitive and diffusion contribution at a scan rate of 1.0 mV s−1 are shown in Figure 7c
Figure 6. a,b) First two-cycle charge-discharge curves and the corresponding in situ XRD patterns collected at the selected charge/discharge states between 0.5 and 2.9 V at different current density of B-FeSe2/G.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900356 (8 of 9)Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1900356
and Figure S8c (Supporting Information). The proportion of the capacitive contribution in the total charge storage for the P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G electrodes is 82.9% and 90.5%, respectively. The ratio of the capacitive contribution to the diffusion contribution at different scan rates for P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G is shown in Figure 7d. As expected, the capacitive contribution gradually increases as the scan rate increases, indicating that a larger capacitive contribution is beneficial for Na ion storage and guarantees a high rate capability for B-FeSe2/G.
The electrochemical impedance spectra measurement (EIS) was performed to further understand the enhanced electrochemical performance of the as-prepared B-FeSe2/G. As displayed in Figure 7e and Figure S9 (Supporting Information), the resistances of the electrolyte and cell components (Rs), the solid electrolyte interface (SEI), and the charge-transfer resistance (Rct) of the B-FeSe2/G are much smaller than that of P-FeSe2, demonstrating that the B-FeSe2/G exhibit better conductivity and reaction kinetics, which is beneficial for improving the electrochemical performance. Furthermore, the sodium diffusion coefficient is calculated using the follow Equation
σ= 0.5( / )Na 2 W Na 2D RT AF C (9)
Where R, T, A, and F are the gas constant, absolute temperature, surface area of the anode and Faraday constant, respectively. CNa is the concentration of sodium ion is represented by can, and Warburg coefficient is represented by σw, which is related to Z′ in Equation (10)
σ ω′ = + + −e ct W 1/2Z R R (10)
Where low frequency region is represented by ω, Re, and Rct are kinetics parameters independent of frequency, and plot of Z′ versus the reciprocal square root of the lower angular frequencies (ω−1/2) is represented by σw. In order to obtain the Warburg coefficient (ω), the linear fitting of Z′ versus ω−1/2 is shown in Figure 7f. The calculated results indicate that B-FeSe2/G present faster diffusion rate of Na+-ion (1.57 × 10−12 cm−2 s−1) than P-FeSe2 (5.55 × 10−13 cm−2 s−1).
The SEM and TEM analyses of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G after 100 cycles at rate of 2.5 A g−1 are shown in Figure S10 in the Supporting Information. Volume change is observed for P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G because of the unavoidable conversion reactions during the discharge/charge process. Comparing the SEM and TEM images (Figure 2) of P-FeSe2 with that of B-FeSe2/G before discharge/charge process, the B-FeSe2/G electrode still maintains structural integrity after 100 cycles, while the P-FeSe2 electrode suffers from a thorough structure collapse. These results indicate that the introduction of graphene nanosheets, which not only wrap the surface of FeSe2 nano-microspheres but also stretch into the bulk, could effectively suppress the volume change during the discharge/charge process.
Therefore, the remarkable enhancement in the initial specific capacity, excellent rate capability, and outstanding cycling performance of the B-FeSe2/G anode may be attributed to two aspects. First, the unique nano-microsphere of B-FeSe2/G is well designed due to the self-templated and introduction of grapheme, contributing the large pesedocapacitive performance. Second, the graphene nanosheets are wrapping and interspersing in the surface and interior of nanomicrosphere of B-FeSe2/G, constructing the highly conductive
Figure 7. Quantitative capacitive analysis of sodium storage behavior. CV curves at different scan rate of the a) B-FeSe2/G; Relationship between logarithm redox peak current and logarithm scan rate of the b) B-FeSe2/G; Capacitive contribution and diffusion contribution at 1.0 mV s−1 of the P-FeSe2 and c) B-FeSe2/G; d) Normalized contribution ratio of capacitive at different scan rates. e) Nyquist plots for P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G; The linear fitting of Z´ versus ω−1/2 of P-FeSe2 and B-FeSe2/G.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900356 (9 of 9)Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1900356
network, which is beneficial for the enhancement of the reaction kinetic. Therefore, it can improve electron/ion conductivity and effectively suppress the volume change during the discharge/charge process.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, burr globule-like nano-microspheres structure of FeSe2/G has been fabricated by a facile hydrothermal method using oxide graphene as self-template. This hybrid exhibits high reversible capacity of 486.3, 443.1, 368.8, and 316.8 mAh g−1 at 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, and 10.0 A g−1, respectively. Moreover, more than 99% of capacity retention after 400 cycles at 2.5 A g−1 is obtained. The excellent rate performance and cycling ability of the composite is attributed to the unique nano-microspheres structure using graphene as self-template, which not only wrap the surface of FeSe2 nano-microspheres but also stretch into the bulk. The unique structure could improve the pseudocapacitive contribution to as high as 90.5% at 1.0 mV s−1, which is thus responsible to the measured superior rate capability. Meanwhile, graphene matrix serves as a conducting 3D network, which is beneficial to the diffusion of Na+ ions and the conduction of electrons, as well to the suppression of the volume change during the discharge/charge process. The excellent electrochemical performance of the B-FeSe2/G nano-microspheres makes it a promising anode material for SIBs.
Supporting Information Supporting Information is available from the Wiley Online Library or from the author.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201900356 larger radius (0.102 vs 0.076 nm for Na+ vs Li+) and heavier molar mass (22.99 vs 6.94 g mol−1 for Na+ vs Li+), Na+ ion diffusion in the electrode materials is more difficult than Li+.[2] Consequently, the large volume change, low specific capacity, inferior rate capability, and poor cycling stability of the electrode materials during the discharge/charge significantly plague the application of SIBs. It thus remains a grand challenge to suppress the volume change during the discharge/charge process, and to further improve the electronic conductivity of the electrode materials for high-performance SIBs. Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), such as MoSe2, CoSe2, FeS2, and MoS2, have received considerable amount of attention as the promising anode materials for SIBs because of their high theoretical capacity and widespread availability. Among them, FeSe2 has attracted great interest due to its abundant resources, low toxicity, high theoretical capacity and environment-friendliness.[6] However, as similar as other TMDs, the development of FeSe2 is limited by the large volume change during the discharge/charge process, resulting in the severe capacity fade caused by unstable structure and poor rate capability induced by electrode pulverization and particle aggregation.[6b] Enormous efforts have been conducted to overcome the issues, while encapsulating the FeSe2 into the carbon matrix is considered as effective approach.[7] For example, Zhang et al.[6c] prepared FeSe2 microspheres interspersed into sulfur-doped reduced graphene oxide sheets as a promising anode for SIBs, displaying an excellent electrochemical performance. It indicates that combining FeSe2 with carbon can suppress the volume change and enhance the electrochemical properties during the continuous sodiation/desodiation process.[7] Whereas, the reaction kinetic with high-rate capability of FeSe2 anode is rarely concerned, which is still needed to address. Although incorporating conductive materials or constructing nanosized structure, the rate ability of FeSe2-based anodes is still far from satisfactory. Generally, apart from the conventional diffusion-controlled behavior in the electrochemical processes, pseudocapacitivecontrolled contribution, as a fast charge-transfer reactions based on the featuring Faradaic surface, plays a crucial role Pseudocapacitance is a Faradaic process that involves surface or near surface redox reactions. Increasing the pseudocapacitive contribution is one of the most effective means to improve the rate performance of electrode materials. In this study, graphene oxide is used as a template to in situ synthesize burr globule-like FeSe2/graphene hybrid (B-FeSe2/G) using a facile one-step hydrothermal method. Structural characterization demonstrates that graphene layers not only wrap the surfaces of FeSe2 particles, but also stretch into the interior of these particles, as a result of which the unique nano-microsphere structure is successfully established. When serving as anode material for Na-ion batteries, B-FeSe2/G hybrid displays high electrochemical performance in the voltage range of 0.5–2.9 V. The B-FeSe2/G hybrid has high reversible capacity of 521.6 mAh·g−1 at 1.0 A g−1. Meanwhile, after 400 cycles, high discharge capacity of 496.3 mAh g−1 is obtained at a rate of 2.5 A g−1, with a high columbic efficiency of 96.6% and less than 1.0% loss of discharge capacity. Even at the ultrahigh rate of 10 A g−1, a specific capacity of 316.8 mAh g−1 can be achieved. Kinetic analyses reveal that the excellent performance of the B-FeSe2/G hybrid is largely attributed to the high pseudocapacitive contribution induced by the special nano-micro structure.
